Since his business is going well, he wants to make soup that tastes more delicious. Thus, he decided to ask for a loan to buy more ingredients to make soup. His wife, Mrs. Khut Sokha, is a farmer who owns a 3 hectare field of land to cultivate rice. Mr. Chantha S. is 39 years old and the father of seven children, two of whom are car cleaners while the others are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients to make soup.

loans.name: Mot

texts.en: Mr. Mot K. is a 28 years old and a resident of Siem Reap province. He is a single man and currently lives with his supportive mother, who appears in the picture above. To make a living, Mot K. works in construction, earning approximately $4 per day. He also helps his mother in doing farm work when he is free from his job. In the past, Mot K. has paid a lot of money for a taxi to go to work because he does not own a vehicle. To cut this cost, Mot K. has requested a loan to buy a used motorcycle which will allow him to drive to his work location.

loans.use: To buy a used motorcycle which will allow him to drive to his work location

loans.name: Santiago

texts.es:
EL Señor Santiago D. Vera es de la Ciudad de Guayaybi, se dedica al negocio de venta de bebidas en general y minutas (empanadas, chipas, milanesas, croquetas, en la segunda actividad  su esposa le ayuda en la preparación de los comestibles.
También se dedica con sus hijos, a la venta y mantenimiento de Antenas Parabólicas,   por toda la zona de Guayaybi.
El negocio cuenta con algunas carencias como falta de herramientas de trabajo y mercaderías además de la necesidad de mejorar la casilla donde realizan sus ventas de comestibles como(pinturas´luces´butacas, carteles, mostrador), para brindar comodidad a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Señor Santiago Dominiguez Vera is from Guayabi city. He has a business selling general drinks and snacks like empanadas, chipas, milanesas, and croquetas which are a variety of breads with different fillings. His wife helps with their preparation. With his children he also sells and maintains satellite dishes throughout the Guayaybi area. This business has a few shortcomings such as the lack of tools and materials. Also, they need to improve the store where they sell their food with things like artwork, lights, chairs, menus and a display case to make their clients more comfortable.

Translated from Spanish by Sierra Visher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy tools, materials and store improvements

loans.name: Samuel Francisco Group

texts.en:
The communal bank of “Samuel Francisco” is comprised of twenty hardworking men and women who are dedicated to various independent businesses. These businesses include shops that specialize in dressmaking as well as shops that sell curtains, furniture, iron lamps, clothing, perfumes, silver jewelry, fast food, fruit, and/or vegetables. Each member plans on investing their portion of the group loan in purchasing merchandise and other stock items that will help them grow their respective business.

The members of “Samuel Francisco” are from Talca, a city in the Maule region of central Chile. The two communities in Talca that the group members come from are called Samuel and Francisco, which is how their communal bank name was made. The climate in the region is Mediterranean, so the land is great for wineries and is a very scenic area. Nevertheless, the region is one of the poorest in Chile.

Mariela is the president of “Samuel Francisco” communal bank and she is pictured above wearing a green T-shirt in the second row. She sells clothing and perfume and travels twice a month to Santiago to purchase her merchandise. Mariela has two children, aged 11 and 9, and she is currently expecting her third child. Her dream is to have a clothing shop of her own in the city center.

For Mariela, Fondo Esperanza has meant important and sustaining economic help for her business, helping her achieve more financial stability for her family.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise to sell

loans.name: Felomina

texts.en: Felomina C., 50 years old, makes and sells Polvoron (a sweet delicacy) and fish in Talibon, Bohol. She works everyday to earn her daily income. She has two adult children and she endures working so hard to be able to provide all the needs of her family. She said that her business has helped a lot to provide for their daily needs. That is why she is doing the best way she can to prosper and improve the turnaround in her business. She wants to re-apply for a loan of PHP 12,000. The loan will go for buying more fish to resell.

loans.use: To obtain more fish to sell

loans.name: Zeneyda

texts.es:
La señora Zeneyda Martinez se dedica a la elaboración y venta de lácteos tales como queso, cuajada y crema siendo preparados por ella y comercializados en el mercado  la Terminal en León. Ella inicia su trabajo desde muy tempranas horas de la mañana y con gran dedicación continúa la venta con el fin de obtener los ingresos que le permitan llevar el sustento a su hogar.
Ella está solicitando un crédito para la compra de los lácteos para llevar a cabo la venta y de esta manera satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes que le solicitan el producto para su respectivo consumo.
texts.en:
Sra. Zeneyda prepares and sells dairy products such as cheese, curds, and cream at the terminal market in León. She begins working early in the morning and, with great dedication, continues with her sales so that she can generate the income needed to sustain her household.

She is requesting a loan to purchase the milk needed to prepare and sell her products and satisfy the respective consumption needs of her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase milk for making various dairy products

loans.name: Heang

texts.en: Mrs. Heang T. weaves rattan cupboards to sell. She sells her finished products to buyers who come directly to her house. She makes many sets of rattan before selling out. Her retailers need to wait a week or a few weeks in advance. She also orders baskets from the other villagers and sells them to make additional income. Her husband helps her pick up rattan to sell door-to-door in the village. Recently, Heang T. received orders from her customers, but her products are not sufficient to fill them. So she would like to request a loan in order to buy rattan products from other weavers to satisfy the needs of her customers.

loans.use: To buy rattans products to sell.

loans.name: Ludith

texts.es:
La Sra. Ludith, tiene 41 años, vive en el Distrito D. Tarapoto, Provincia D. San Martin, Departamento D. San Martin, la socia  pertenece al Banco Comunal “Nuestra Señora D. la Paz”, es casada y tiene 03 hijos todos independientes. La Socia presenta estudios D. Primaria Completa.

Ludith, se dedica a la venta D. salchipapas y salchipollos, se encuentra ubicado su negocio en la esquina D. su casa un lugar amplio y acondicionado para atender a sus clientes que diariamente acuden a comprar. Nos cuenta que a diario tiene muy buenas ventas,  es conocida y tiene muy buena acogida. Con su primer crédito D. 300 Nuevos Soles, compró ingredientes para el preparado D. sus alimentos cómo, sacos D. papa, hot dog (salchicha), sal en paquetes , plátano en racimos y parte del dinero lo invirtió en comprar platos descartables , cucharas , etc. 

Con este crédito  D. S/ 1,500.00 Nuevos Soles, comprará insumos para la preparación diaria D. sus alimentos cómo, sacos D. papa, plátanos en racimos, pollos en jabas y condimentos para aderezar sus alimentos y también  algunos utensilios, para dar una mejor atención a sus clientes. 

Ludith se siente llena D. vida y con ganas D. seguir adelante, su sueño es tener un Restaurant muy bien acondicionado y vender comidas regionales y al mismo tiempo también agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir  en iniciar su negocio.
texts.en:
Ludith is 41, and she lives in the Tarapoto district, San Martin province, San Martin department. She belongs to the Nuestra Señora D. la Paz Communal Bank. She is married and has three children who are all independent. She has an elementary school education. Ludith sells "salchipapas" (food maD. from fried potatoes and fried sausages) and "salchipollos" (food maD. from fried potatoes and fried chicken). Her business is located on the corner of her house in a spacious area that is equipped to wait on her customers who buy from her daily. She tells us that she has very good daily sales. She is well-known, and her business is well received. With her first loan for 300 PEN she bought ingredients for food preparation like sacks of potatoes, hot dogs (sausages), packages of salt, and bunches of bananas. She used part of the money to buy disposable plates and spoons, etc. With this loan for 1,500 PEN she will buy supplies for daily food preparation. She will buy things like sacks of potatoes, bunches of bananas, crates of chicken, and condiments to season her food. She will also buy some utensils to give her customers better service. Ludith feels full of life with the desire to keep going forward. Her dream is to have a well equipped restaurant and to sell regional food. At the same time she is also grateful to the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for contributing to the start of her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy ingredients for food preparation

loans.name: Adelarda

texts.en:
Adelarda M. is from the village of D'ban, Calamba Misamis Occidental. She is 67 years old and a widow with 3 adult children. She has owned and managed her flower farm for 25 years with a monthly net income of 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP), which is about $219 US. Through her business she has been able to support her family.

In 2002, she joined PMPC to gain access the financial services extended by the co-op.  After successfully repaying a previous loan, her fifth, she is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP that will be used as additional capital for her business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for flower farm

loans.name: Anita

texts.en: Anita T. is a 60-year-old married woman who lives in Barangay 1, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by engaging in a general store and peanut and balut-vending businesses (a balut is a fertilized duck egg with a nearly-developed embryo inside that is boiled and eaten in the shell). Anita’s husband, Suelo, is a tricycle driver. They have six adult children who are between 20 ad 40 years old with some of them having their own families and their own work. Anita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in her general store, peanut and balut-vending businesses. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 5,000 from her business activities. Anita is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 19,000 was used to fund operations of her general store, peanut and balut-vending businesses which had a positive impact on both the businesses and on the family’s living conditions. Now, Anita is borrowing Php 19,500 as her 22nd loan which she intends to use for her general store, peanut and balut-vending businesses. She is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her businesses

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha is married to a mechanic and sells used clothes. She has been in this business for one year and sells her products from a stall near her home. Her men's clothing is the easiest to sell. Martha travels to Nairobi twice a month to buy stock. Her greatest challenges are finding customers and the rainy season (as her stall does not have a roof). In addition, transportation for her products is a challenge.
With her 40,000 KES loan, Martha wants to purchase more clothes to sell. She aspires to grow her business and open a shop in town in the future. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and rent. Martha describes herself as honest, down-to-earth and hardworking. She is pictured with her older sister (wearing a white t-shirt) who helps her with her business sometimes.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Teresita's Group

texts.en:
Teresita A. is from the village of Casalatan, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 54 years old. Teresita is the group leader of a 15-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Teresita is married and has 9 school-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns & operates a business venture in the food sector selling a variety of vegetables. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from vegetable vending. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Teresita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Teresita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: La Union Group

texts.es:
La Sra. Maricela tiene 35 años de edad, tiene un pequeño hijo, vive feliz junto con su pareja que la apoya en todo y su hijo en la zona de la libertad en el distrito de comas, al igual que sus 6 compañeras que forman parte del grupo "la unión", y fueron sus compañeros quienes la eligieron como presidenta de la junta directiva del grupo.

Hace seis años la sra. Maricela se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza, y ultimamente apoya en un salon de belleza. Las necesidades familiares la animaron a buscar generarse un ingreso extra que pudiera ayudar en la economía del hogar, es así que empieza vendiendo productos de belleza por catalogo.

Gracias a su trabajo puede asumir algunos gastos personales yu apoyar a su esposo.

Su proxima meta es poner un salon de belleza por lo que se esfuerza mucho en su negocio.
El prestamo solicitado lo utilizará para pagar algunas deudas generadas por su negocio.
texts.en:
Maricela is 35 years old and has one small child. She lives happily in the Libertad area of the Comas District with her partner, who supports her in everything, and her son. Her 6 fellow members of the “La Unión” group also live in Libertad and elected her as president of the group’s management committee. Six years ago, Maricela began selling beauty products and lately has been helping in a beauty salon. The needs of her family motivated her to seek a way of earning additional income to contribute to the household finances, which is how she started selling mail-order beauty products. Thanks to her work she can meet some personal expenses and also help her husband. Her next goal is to set up a beauty salon, so she is working very hard in her current business. The loan requested will be used to pay some debts generated by her business.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Stansfield, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will use the loan to pay business debts

loans.name: Tahira Bibi's Group

texts.en:
Tahira Bibi is doing a great job in helping her husband to fulfill the basic needs of the family. She has a boutique and sells clothes and other embroidered products such as shawls and handkerchiefs at a good profit. She has been doing this work for over six years.

Her business is limited to her community, but she wants to start doing business on a larger scale. For this purpose, she has applied for a loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). With the loan, she will buy a variety of clothes and embroidered items in bulk, which will help her to introduce her work in different clothes shops and to get good orders from them too.

She is very hopeful about the bright future of her boutique business.

loans.use: To purchase the required items for her boutique business.

loans.name: Walter Macadeo

texts.es: El solicitante es soltero, viene trabajando como chofer de mototaxi desde hace mas de 3 años teniendo como ingreso semanal de S/. 300.00. El destino del credito es para mantenimiento de su vehiculo y para invertir en un negocio de abarrotes. Tiene como meta comprarse su propia mototaxi
texts.en:
The applicant is single. He has been working as a “mototaxi” (three wheeled motorized vehicle) driver for over three years. His weekly income is 300 soles. The loan is to perform maintenance on his vehicle. He will also use it to invest in a grocery business. His goal is to buy his own mototaxi.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Mainenance on his "mototaxi"

loans.name: Beyola

texts.en: Beyola J. is currently in the business of selling maize flour, rice and beans at her store and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of beans and rice to sell. Beyola is 39 years old and her husband is a businessman. She has 3 children, all attending school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor area of her store.

loans.use: Stock more bags of beans and rice to sell

loans.name: El Progreso Group

texts.es:
ALCANCIA COMUNAL “EL PROGRESO”

La alcancía comunal “EL PROGRESO” es un grupo formado por 9 socias y 1 socio que viven en una misma urbanización, con el tiempo D. casi 4 años trabajando con EDAPROSPO-PORSPERIDAD han formado una buena amistad porque han mostrado ayuda a sus compañeras y ser mas activas en el grupo.

Tina tiene 38 años D. edad, tiene 2 hijos que aun depenD. D. ella y vive con su esposo en su casa propia, ella se dedica a vender fruta en el mercado que esta cerca a su casa, es un puesto que lo alquila a mercado, y por lo que es un negocio propio le da la libertad D. ser la tesorera D. la alcancía comunal

Ella tiene mucho empeño y entusiasmo junto con su compañeras D. alcancía comunal, Tina sale muy temprano a un terminal que esta muy lejos D. su casa para conseguir la fruta en gran cantidad a un menor precio para ofrecerla en el mercado donD. ella venD., y así ganar el dinero para el sustento D. su familia.

Tina sueña con ver a sus hijos profesionales y dar refacción a su casa.
texts.en:
“El Progreso” Communal Bank The “El Progreso” Communal Bank is a group maD. up of 9 female members and one male member who all live in the same neighborhood. Having worked for almost 4 years with EDAPROSPO-PROSPERIDAD, they have formed a close friendship because they have helped each other out and become more active in the group. Tina is 38 years old. She has 2 children that still depend on her and she lives with her husband in their own house. She sells fruit in the market that is close to her house. She rents a place in the market and since it is her own business she is able to act as the treasurer of the communal bank. She is very hardworking and enthusiastic, as are her fellow members of the communal bank. Tina leaves very early in the morning to go to a bus terminal that is far from her house to get the fruit in large quantities at a lower price so she can sell it in the market she works from. This is how she earns the money to proviD. for her family. Tina dreams of seeing her children become professionals and of refurbishing her house.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy fruits such as papaya, oranges, pinapples, apples, pears, plantains, etc. and the transportation for them.

loans.name: Yorn's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Yorn P., 58, is the leader of this group loan, having been selected by its members who all live in Ta Kdol village in Kandal province. All members will use their portion of the loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Yorn P. is a grocery seller in the local village. This business provides a small income to support the family. Since her business is going well, and in order to increase her income to help the family, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries to sell. Mrs. Yorn P. is a widow with a child who is a taxi driver.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Shara Luisa

texts.es: La señora vive en casa propia en la zona de Callampaya de la ciudad de La Paz, es soltera y actualmente estudia la carrera de  Derecho, su actividad es la venta de productos de belleza  Avon, por la misma recibe comisiones por ventas. Por las mañanas trabaja como procuradora en el Edificio Alborada  donde percibe un salario mínimo. El crédito que solicita es para aumentar su capital y poder surtir su mercadería y mantener esta fuente de ingresos estable, es la primera vez que obtiene un crédito en Impro y forma parte de Kiva.
texts.en:
She lives in her own home in La Paz’s Callampaya neighborhood. She is single and is studying Law. She sells Avon beauty products and receives a commission on her sales. During the mornings she works for minimum wage as a Building Representative at the Alborada Building. The requested funds will be to increase her capital to buy stock merchandise so that she can keep this source of income stable. This is the first time that she’s gotten a loan from Impro and been a part of Kiva.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stock inventory items.

loans.name: Jose Luis

texts.es: José Luis tiene 24 años por lo que es una joven con muchas ganas de salir adelante. El se dedica a la venta de productos varios como medicinas naturales. Hace más de 2 años que tiene este negocio, por lo que ha luchado por mantener su actividad que no ha sido muy fácil, el es un hombre muy trabajador que disfruta de este trabajo se encuentra muy contento con financiamiento, pues lo solicito para la compra de productos herbalife. Sueña con comprar su propia casa.
texts.en:
José Luis, 24, is a young man with a strong wish to get ahead in life. He sells various products like natural remedies. He’s had this business for over 2 years. He has struggled to stay in business because it hasn’t been easy. He is a hard working man who enjoys his work and is very happy with the financing because he requested it to buy Herbalife products. He dreams with buying his own house.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy Herbalife products.

loans.name: Residenciales El Campo N° 2 Group

texts.es: El grupo solidario Residenciales El Campo #2 está integrado por tres socias, los cuales realizan diferentes actividades económicas. Doña Elbia es una las socias, tiene 51 años de edad, es viuda y tiene cinco hijos. De lunes a viernes, ella tiene un empleo fijo como aseadora y el fin de semana vende verduras. El problema más difícil que enfrenta es que no tiene una vivienda propia, y los directivos de la escuela le dieron permiso para que construyera una habitación dentro de las instalaciones de la misma y gracias a los préstamos obtenidos en FAMA pudo hacerlo aunque es muy pequeña para su familia. Su reto es ahorrar aunque sea de poco en poco para comprar un solar y poder construir su casa, seguir manteniendo a su familia porque hace dos años su esposo murió y no tiene ningún otro soporte económico. Elbia solicita el préstamo para comprar papas, chiles, cebollas, zanahorias, pataste, repollo, etc. y así ofrecer una mayor variedad de productos a sus clientes. Una de sus ventajas es que su hijo mayor le ayuda a transportar en una carreta las verduras desde su casa al mayoreo y no tiene que pagar transporte ni empleado porque él también le ayuda a atender a los clientes. Con el apoyo del préstamo espera obtener mejores ganancias para ahorrar un poco, seguir llevando el alimento a su casa y seguir pagando el estudio de sus cuatro hijos menores. Su sueño es tener también un puesto de venta de ropa para contar con otra entrada de dinero y así poder empezar a construir su casa, y graduar a sus hijos. Elbia se siente muy agradecida porque con el financiamiento obtenido en FAMA ha podido mejorar sus condiciones económicas y de antemano se siente agradecida con todas las personas que invertirán en ella a través del préstamo.
texts.en:
The “Residenciales El Campo #2” (El Campo Residences #2) group consists of three members who do different economic activities.

Mrs. Elbia, 51, is one of the members.  She’s a widow and has five children.  From Monday to Friday she has a steady job working as a Cleaning Lady and on weekends she sells vegetables.

The greatest obstacle she faces is not owning her own home and the school administrators gave her permission to build a room on the school grounds.  Thanks to FEMA loans she was able to do so although it is too small for her family.

Her challenge now is to save up, even if just bit by bit, to buy a piece of property on which to build her house and to continue supporting her family because her husband died two years ago and she has no other source of income.

Elbia is requesting funds to buy potatoes, chilies, onions, carrots, chayote, cabbage, etc. in order to have a wider variety available for her customers.
An advantage she has is that her oldest son helps her move the vegetables from home to the wholesale market with a cart so she doesn’t have to pay transport costs nor hire an employee since he helps her tend to customers too.

With support from the loan she hopes to earn better profits so that she can start to have some savings, continue to bring food home and pay for her four youngest children’s education.  Her dream is to also have a stand to sell clothing to have a second source of income and start to build her house and have her children graduate.

Elbia is very grateful because financing from FEMA has helped her improve her economic conditions and she would like to thank everyone ahead of time who will invest in her through the loan.

loans.use: To buy vegetables.

loans.name: Ibrahim's Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is pleased to present to you teachers of the Kankalay Islamic Primary School. This school was founded in 1992 by the Kankalay Mission as a response to the community’s request for an educational center in the community. The Kankalay Islamic Primary School is currently staffed with 15 teachers and has an enrollment of 350 pupils.

Thirty-six-year-old Ibrahim D. is the leader of this group and headmaster at the school. Ibrahim was born in a village called Royainkain in northern Sierra Leone.  He has been in the teaching profession for 10 years now. He is married and has four children. Three of the children are in primary school and one is in secondary school. Ibrahim is going to invest his share of this loan in business. He will buy locally-produced goods such as rice and palm oil at wholesale to sell. 

This is the first loan that teachers of this school are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. School staff from this institution, like many other schools staff within SMT’s operational areas, come to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise have not being able to accomplish with their mere salaries alone. But with the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, house-building materials, or to invest in business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

loans.use: To buy locally-produced goods such as rice and palm oil at wholesale to sell

loans.name: Purevtseren

texts.en:
Purevtseren T. is 47 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Huvsgul province, Mongolia. They live together in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.  His oldest two children attend school while Purevtseren operates a gold and silver crafts business in his town.

He is a dexterous craftsman who received all his skills from his elders. He designs and produces a variety of jewelry and accessories using his father's equipment and tools. He has been engaged in this business for 8 years and has built a stable operation. For the future, he plans to have his own workplace next to his home.

Purevtseren is a modest man who is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase his mould and supplies from Erlian, a border city in China, for his jewelery making business.

loans.use: To purchase supplies from Erlian

loans.name: Rukiya

texts.en:
Rukiya is a widowed woman with five children, one of whom attend school while four graduated from school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She operates a natural soft drink making business, selling from home to her neighbours and passers-by. Rukiya faces a major challenge of seasonality. During the rainy winter season, the demand for soft drinks is lower compared to the hot summer season, when the demand rises. She hopes to own a parlour in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000, she wants to purchase pumps to do plumbing in the home. She decided to join Yehu, because it provides sustainable financial services.

loans.use: To purchase pumps for home plumbing

loans.name: Nemesia

texts.en:
Nemesia C. is a single woman who lives in Barangay Santo Niño, Malabuyoc, Cebu. She earns her living by operating 3 business ventures: pig fattening, Manicure/Pedicure services and food vending. Nemesia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 8 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Nemesia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 9th loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,000, which she intends to use as additional working capital so that she can continue to save up for the future to provide her with more income and to support the needs of her family. Nemesia C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital.

loans.name: Rolando

texts.en:
Rolando M. is from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. He is single and 38 years old. To make a living, Rolando owns and operates a specialized retail store. His main source of income comes primarily from buying and selling coconuts in the local community, and he also buys and sells soft drinks. Rolando has been engaged in his business for over seven years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

Rolando joined HSPFI in 2010 to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rolando has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital. For his second loan, he is requesting 4,000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell such as coconuts. Roland plans to use the additional revenue generated from his business to improve and expand. 


About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: TO CONSTRUCT ONE WALL AND REPLACE OTHER WALLS ON HER PROPERTY

loans.name: Shameem's Group

texts.en:
Shameem comes from Okara which is a small city in Pakistan, known for its agriculture industry. She lives there in the area named Kot Nihal Singh with her family in a 2-room brick house. She moved here 9 years ago. She is 35 years old and married to H. M. who works in a government organization for a low income. 

Shameem supports her family by doing sewing work. She does the work according to orders which she receives from neighborhood clients. She has a good number of clients due to her quality of work. She uses the income in paying their utility bills and the school fees for her children. 

Shameem is the mother of five sons. Three of them are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to further improve her business of sewing. She will use the loan money in buying a new sewing machine because her previous machine has become old and is not producing a quality work. The new machine will help her finish orders on time so she receives more orders every month. She has been operating this business for over 8 years and is very hopeful that it will expand further after the loan investment. 
   
She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine for sewing business

loans.name: Valeria

texts.es:
La Sra. Valeria tiene 53 años. Ella es soltera y sus hijos son todos mayores de edad. Una de sus hijas tuvo que viajar al exterior para trabajar y por ello fue quien le brindó la ayuda para iniciar su taller de costura en el año 2007. Empezó tomando pedidos particulares de confección sobre medida, luego fue visitando oficinas y sus propias clientes la recomendaban con otras personas.
Hoy ya cuenta con una clientela formada, también confecciona uniformes para una escuela, tanto para los alumnos como para las docentes.
Necesita de este crédito para comprar un lote de telas aprovechando una oferta que se le presentó. Pues ya debe iniciar la confección de uniformes escolares.
Su anhelo es que su hija pueda regresar al país y estar juntas nuevamente.
texts.en:
Valeria is 53 years old, single, and her children are all grown. One of her daughters needed to travel outside the country to work and she was able to provide assistance in setting up her sewing shop in the year 2007. She started taking custom orders but later she started visiting businesses and existing clients gave their recommendations to others. 

Today she depends on a steady clientele. She makes school uniforms for the students and for the teachers. 

She requires this loan to purchase a measure of fabrics, taking advantage of the special offer presented to her. She needs to start making school uniforms. 

Her goal is to see her daughter return to the country and to be together again.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics, threads and accessories, such as buttons, ribbons, needles, etc.

loans.name: Meriam

texts.en:
Meriam G. is from the village of Estrella, Sinacaban, Misamis Occdental. She is 42 years old. Meriam is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Meriam owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. Meriam has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Meriam joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Meriam is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the first loan taken out by Meriam from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Vahe

texts.en:
Vahe H. lives in Hartashen village of Syunik region. Vahe lives with his mother, grandmother and brother. 

The family’s main income comes from agricultural. Vahe’s family’s living conditions were quite bad. Unable to find a job locally, Vahe’s father left the homeland to work abroad. Now Vahe personally takes care of everything.

Vahe’s dream is to expand the business enough to ensure sufficient income for this family and to bring his father back home. 

Vahe has applied for the loan to increase the number of cattle.

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Naise

texts.es: Naise, de 19 años, trabaja arduamente por apoyar a sus padres: Oscar y Luz. A quienes ama mucho, además de sus hermano Lenin. Con quienes vive en armonía familiar en su casa propia, ubicada en el caserío de Cayan. A pesar de su corta edad, supo adquirir no solo la experiencia necesaria para obtener buenos frutos, también sus propios terrenos agrícolas, en donde siembra papa, maíz y arveja. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es poder trabajar en beneficio suyo. Asimismo tiene una tienda de comestibles, donde vende productos de primera necesidad como: azúcar, leche, huevo y demás alimentos. Según menciona, vende un promedio de S/. 60 nuevos soles cada día. Su principal dificultad es el capital de trabajo, pues para que obtenga ganancias inmediatas tiene que surtir en productos diversos para su tienda, ya que en la agricultura invierte la mayor parte de sus ingresos. Los sueños de Naise, es crear una tienda grande y surtida para los pobladores de su localidad. Ella pertenece al banco comunal “Siempre juntos”, y este es el primer crédito con MFP, donde agradece la oportunidad que le dieron para poder concretizar sus proyectos. Naise, se está preparando para la cosecha de sus sembríos de maíz en los primeros días de Marzo, por ello con el crédito está pensando comprar varios sacos de abono; con los que espera obtener buenas ganancias.
texts.en:
Naise is 19 years old.  She works hard to support her parents Oscar and Luz who she loves very much, and also her brother Lenin.  They live together peacefully as a family in their own home which is located in the village of Cayan.  In spite of her young age, Naise has managed to acquire not only the experience she needs to ensure good harvests but also her own farmland where she grows potatoes, corn and peas.  What she most likes about her work is being able to work for herself.

Naise also owns a grocery store where she sells essentials such as sugar, milk, eggs and other food products.  She tells us that she sells an average of 60 Peruvian soles' worth of goods every day.  The main difficulty she faces in her business is that of working capital since, in order to make immediate profits, she has to stock her store with a range of products.  Most of her money is tied up in her farming.

Naise's dream is to create a big, well-stocked store for the residents of her village.  She belongs to the "Siempre Juntos" (Always Together) community bank and this is her first loan with MFP.  She is grateful for the opportunity that they have given her to carry out her plans.  Naise is getting prepared for the harvesting of her corn crop at the beginning of March.  She will use her loan to buy several sacks of manure which she hopes will allow her to obtain good profits.

loans.use: to buy sacks of organic manure

loans.name: God Bless Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “God Bless” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Adama S.. Adama S. is age 30; she was born in a place called Sanda, near Makeni city. But currently, she is residing in Makeni together with her husband and two children. Her husband is a businessman and her children are attending primary and secondary schools. For eight years now, Adama has been selling firewood and palm oil (the country’s favorite cooking oil). With her share of this loan,  she will buy firewood and palm oil in large quantity to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: to buy firewood and palm oil in large quantity.

loans.name: Amada

texts.en:
Amada G. is from the village of Barangay 26, Gingoog City. She is 56 years old. Amada is married and has two school-aged children. 

To make a living, Amada owns and operates a a mini-restaurant, serving a variety of meals like afritada, fried fish and pork, caldereta and fish soups to customers in the local community. Amada has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Amada joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Amada has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase food and drinks for the restaurant. 

Amada is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional ingredients like meat, spices and vegetables. This will be the third loan taken out by Amada from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients like meat, spices and vegetables

loans.name: Fawzi

texts.en:
Fawzi is a 42-year-old married man who lives in Chtoura with his wife and five children. He is a mechanic. Since 2001, he has owned a garage where he fixes cars. Fawzi is a hard worker and loved by most of his clients, who are his friends and neighbors. He has 27 years of experience and his good reputation is his strength among his competitors. 

Fawzi is requesting his first loan from Al Majmoua to buy new equipment necessary to improve his business and also to pay for his daughter's engagement expenses. In the future, Fawzi plans to open a grocery store to help cover his family’s expenses.

loans.use: to buy business equipment and pay for his daughter's engagement expenses

loans.name: Gulpotkan's Group

texts.en:
Gulpotkan E. leads this loan group.  She is 57 years old, married to a pensioner and is the mother of six children, three daughters and three sons. All of her children are married and most of them live independently with their own families (under Kyrgyz traditions the youngest son continues to live with his parents). Seven years ago, Gulpotkan went into business breeding livestock, reselling animals for a good price after spending a lot of time feeding and caring for them. She and her husband now earn 2,000 soms a month from their business and would like to buy a vehicle for their son to use. She will use her portion of this loan to buy more livestock to breed. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to buy livestock to raise and breed.

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kalerwe in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is single and has one child, who is not currently in school.  Edith has a business of selling clothes, which she has had for less than one year.         

To help expand her business, Edith has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more clothes for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Edith hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  In the future, Edith hopes to own a salon.        Edith is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her positive behaviors through life planning skills.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Elena works hard to support her family.

She has a tobacco-sales business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a general store.  Elena is borrowing 25,000 PHP through NWTF to buy stocks of tobacco to sell.

Elena has been sustaining her business activities through her past 13 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money so she can continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy stocks of tobacco to sell

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a single woman who owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, electricity, and clothing.

Asha operates a beauty salon business; her potential customers are neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of competition from other beauty salon operators in the area.  Asha dreams of establishing another beauty salon in the future.

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase cosmetics and hair weaves. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics and hair weaves.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 49 years old and lives in Congo Town. She is married and her husband is a driver. They have ten children ages 9 to 33 years old. Four live at home and six are married.

For the past five years Mary has been operating a little restaurant where she sells Liberian food. She started this business with 2,500 LRD. She enjoys her business because she has a lot of customers.

She is requesting a loan to purchase rice, oil, fish and spices for her business. She plans to build a house in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase rice, oil, fish and spices for her business.

loans.name: Oretha

texts.en: Oretha is 42 years old and lives in Jacob Town. She is married and has one child, age 20 years. For five years now, she has been selling charcoal in the local market. She started this business with the help of her husband. She enjoys her business because it gives her a lot of profit. She is requesting a loan to purchase more goods for her business. She plans to buy a car in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Juana Del Carmen

texts.es:
Juana es madre soltera de cuatro hijos y de estos actualmente dependen tres de ella y estos se encuentran actualmente en el colegio, ella trabaja  como secretaria en la ciudad de managua desde hace ya varios años. ella visita las oficina de ceprodel por primera vez para solicitar un prestamo para pagar deudas familiares del hogar que la estan agobiando.es primera ves que trabaja con ceprodel.

agradece a ceprodel por el apoyo brindado ya que ahora ella podra darles mejores condicines a su familia en su hogar.
texts.en:
Juana is a single mother with four children, three of whom still live at home.  The three children at home are all in school.  Juana has worked as a secretary in Managua for many years.  She came to Ceprodel recently to apply for a loan to repay debts that have been weighing the family down.  This is her first Ceprodel loan.

She is grateful to Ceprodel for its support because the loan will help her to improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: to repay a loan.

loans.name: Rathanak

texts.en:
Rathanak is a housewife. Her husband is a Tok Tok (motorcycle taxi) driver who earns $7 per day. She has three children, two of whom are studying. Every month, she has to spend $75 on food, $3 on electricity, $5 on school fees, $15 on transportation and $10 on other expenses. 

She would like to request a loan of $700 to buy a motorbike to replace her husband's current motorbike because it is old and needs a lot of fixing. In the future, she wants to have a job so that she can help her husband by earning some money for supporting the family.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband's taxi service

loans.name: Johana

texts.es: Johana es una joven emprendedora quien hace poco decidió montar su propio negocio, una heladería ubicada en Amagá municipio que hace parte del departamento de Antioquia, allí trabaja diariamente de 10:00 a.m. a 9:00 p.m. con la ilusión de salir adelante y generar ingresos por sus propios medios, se preocupa por brindar un buen servicio y que sus clientes se deleiten con exquicitos helado; sin embargo no cuenta con el capital que necesita para invertirle al negocio, motivo por el cual hoy solicita un préstamo con el cual hacer algunas adecuaciones al local, comprar un enfriador y un surtido adecuado para ofrecer calidad y cantidad en sus productos e igualmente poder generar un ingreso economico para su sostenimiento. Aunque para Johana es duro no vivir actualmente en compañia de de su familia, ya que debe estar al frente de su negocio, sabe que podrá ayudar a su familia a tener un mejor futuro, y así mismo a tener una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: Johana is a young businesswoman who decided to begin her own business a short time ago. It's an ice cream store located in the municipality of Amagá which forms part of the department of Antioquia. She works there daily from 10am to 9pm with the desire to get ahead and generate her own income. Nevertheless, she doesn't have the capital she needs to invest in the business which is why she is requesting the loan to make some improvements to her store such as purchasing a freezer and an adequate supply of products to be able to offer quality and quantity in her products as well as generate an economic income for her sustainability. Although it's difficult for Johana to not currently live with her family since she has to be close to her business, she knows that she can help her family to have a better future and thus a better quality of life.

loans.use: Adecuaciones locativas, Compra de un enfriador y surtido.

loans.name: Eulogia

texts.es: La señora Eulogia tiene una tienda el la ciudad de el Alto, donde comercializa los productos nutricionales y naturales, ella vive  en alquiler con sus dos hijos a quienes mantiene ella sola su negocio tiene una antigüedad de aproximadamente   dos años  necesita el crédito para aumentar su capital , comprando variedad de productos nutricionales y naturales para así surtir su tienda que se encuentra en un lugar estratégico de la ciudad del Alto  la señora Eulogia es muy luchadora ya que su sueño es darles una casa propia a sus hijos y una buena educación  para lo cual ella esta ahorrando dinero.
texts.en:
Eulogia has a store in the city of El Alto.  She sells nutritional and natural products.  She rents where she lives with her two children.  She supports them alone.  Her business is approximately two years old.

She needs the loan to buy a variety of nutritious and natural products to stock her store, which is in a strategic place in the city of El Alto.

Eulogia is very tenacious.  Her dream is to give her children their own house and a good education.  She is saving money for this.

loans.use: to buy a variety of nutritional and natural products.

loans.name: Nieves

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “MUJERES UNIDAS”; el banco se encuentra ubicado en el Distrito de San Jeronimo en la Provincia de Cusco y Departamento de Cusco.
La socia es la Sra. Nieves, la socia tiene 38 años de edad, la socia es casada y tiene 2 hijos, la socia se dedica  a la atención de su restaurante, la socia trabaja elaborando diversos potajes, la socia compra arroz, aceite, fideos al por mayor ella atiende su restaurante y se encarga de todos los detalles, La socia desea el crédito para invertir en la compra de arroz, aceite y otros productos. La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de arroz, aceite y otros productos para elaborar las comidas. 
La socia agradece el apoyo que se le otorgara y así mismo se compromete a cumplir de manera disciplinada con los pagos de las cuotas.
texts.en:
Sra. Nieves is a member of the Communal Bank “Mujeres Unidas” which is in the District of San Jeronimo, Province and Department of Cusco.

She is 38 years old, married, and has two children. Nieves manages a restaurant and prepares different dishes using rice, oil, and noodles that she purchases in bulk. As the restaurant manager, she is in charge of all the details. Nieves wants a loan to invest in the purchase of rice, oil, and other products so that she can prepare her dishes.

She is grateful for the support that has been provided and promises to complete her payments in a disciplined manner.

loans.use: to buy rice, oil, and other products for preparing her dishes.

loans.name: Bidii Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Bidii Group in Western Kenya! 
Jodyna is the facilitator of the Bidii Group. She is a mother of three children. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Jodyna had an excellent maize yield harvesting twelve bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Jodyna was only able to harvest five bags of maize on half an acre of land. It is typical for One Acre Fund farmers to double or triple their maize yields after joining the program.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Jodyna and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.
With income from maize sales, Jodyna will pay school fees for her children and buy food for the family.
In 2012, the members of Bidii Group will each plant between half and two acres of maize.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose lives in Uganda. She is single and has 7 children, six of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members. Rose has a restaurant business.  She has been in this business for 5 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Rose sells her products from home, by means of retail. Rose has requested a loan of 100,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas, beef, cassava and rice. She also generates additional income through rental rooms.The main business challenge(s) for Rose include ever increasing prices  of  foodstuffs and  thieves  .  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start growing food stuffs and to own a fully stocked restaurant.   Rose lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding family.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs like  bunches of bananas, rice, cassava and beef

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora is 29 years old and is a married woman. She has four children, two of whom are in school. She has had a business of selling breads in Kator, South Sudan for five years.

Flora requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase breads. She will use her extra income to build a house in future.

loans.use: to purchase breads for sale

loans.name: Larry

texts.en:
Larry is 38 years of age, married and blessed with two school-aged children. He is planting rice crops on his five hectares of farm. He has had this agricultural business for almost 20 years. Larry would like to improve and maintain his rice fields but his income is not enough due to his family household expenses. He is glad to see that his business grows although he experiences hardships.

Larry would like to ask for a loan amount of PHP 30,000 which will be used to buy farm inputs such as fertilizer, herbicides, insecticides and seedlings for his rice fields. He hopes that he can receive the amount that he has requested so that he can send his children into a higher level of education and save some for his family's future. He believes that through his efforts, dedication and additional capital he could be a successful farmer someday.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, herbicides, insecticides and seedlings for his rice fields

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a farmer in Kitale, Western Kenya. She has been in farming for four years and produces eggs, milk, and vegetables for the local market where she also retail cereals.

Grace has requested a loan of 50,000 Kenya shillings (KES) from Kilimo to purchase poultry birds and boost her poultry farming business. She adds that she will use the income to care for her siblings and plan for her future. She is optimistic that she will be able to supply far markets with her eggs.

She points at fluctuation in market prices.

loans.use: To buy poultry birds.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Glenn

texts.en:
Glenn is married with two children. Glenn is 32 years old and lives in the Philippines.

Glenn is providing transportation services to local community members to earn a living. He has been doing this for 10 years and every month he earns 10,000 PHP from this work. He has requested a loan of 30,000 PHP to repair his vehicle for better service.

Glenn has been a member of GDMPC for a year. In the future, Glenn hopes to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to repair his vehicle for better service

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 57 years old and has four children.

Erlinda works hard to provide for her family.  She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 21000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell.

Erlinda has borrowed and paid four loans from NWTF before this loan.  She has been running the general store for eight years and also earns an income from pig fattening.

Erlinda aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy additional items to sell.

loans.name: Kweku

texts.en: Kweku is married and has 4 children.  He sells charcoal at Asebu Brebia, which he has done for ten years.  Kweku uses his income to pay his children’s school fees.  He will use this loan to purchase more firewood for the production of charcoal to sell.  With the new profits from his expanded business, Kweku hopes to educate his children through to the college level.

loans.use: purchase more firewood for the production of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn is a 33-year-old single woman. She describes herself as social, innovative, and good at marketing. She operates a a poultry farm where she sells chickens. She has been involved in this business for 4 years. Her business is located within a market town and her primary customers are farmers, landlords, and businessmen. She describes her biggest business challenges as the high cost of chicken feeds and the outbreak of airborne diseases that affect the chickens. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy chicken feed and more chickens. Her business goal is to be a supplier of chicken within her town and locally.

loans.use: to buy chicken feed and more chickens.

loans.name: Louniely

texts.en:
Louniely is 38 years old and married with eight children. She works very hard to provide for them.

Louniely runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional groceries such as curls, soft drinks, and coffee to sell. Louniely has been in this business for 3 years.

In the future Louniely would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional groceries such as curls, soft drinks, and coffee to sell

loans.name: Na's Group

texts.en:
Na is aged 56 and widowed with six children. Her family lives in a village of the Moung Russey district of Battambang province and she and her husband earn a living through farming rice for 15 years. The current business earns her about 40,000KHR per day.
Na is just with VisionFund for this cycle and now she is leading her group to ask for a loan. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland. She hopes to make more income from her current business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en: Dorcas is a married woman. She has 3 children. She describes herself to be focused. She operates a retail business where she sells clothes. She has been involved in this business for 6 years. Her business is located in a busy area. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of clothes. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. She will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes.

loans.name: Luis

texts.en:
Luis owns a small store where he sells foods and basic house supplies. He and his mother have been in this type of business for over 10 years. He previously owned a shop near the main street of the community, but city officials tore the store and his home down when they expanded the street because the properties were built without a permit. Luis and his mother had to start anew and they are now doing well with the business again. Luis is requesting the loan in order to invest in new products for his store. He is separated from his wife whom he has two children with. The kids live with their mother, but Luis is constantly visiting them and pays child support to help pay for their food and education.

Mifex offers its clients microinsurance and access to business training and educational programs. For more information about microfinance, Ecuador, and our services, please visit www.mifex.org.

loans.use: Luis is requesting the loan in order to invest in new products for his store.

loans.name: Jesús

texts.en:
Jesús works selling cosmetics and clothing to his neighborhood and the surrounding areas. Jesús started this business with the help of a friend who helped her get started by providing merchandise. At the beginning, she only sold cosmetics. Now she also offers clothing and shoes, and in the future she aspires to sell home electronics also.

She will use the loan to invest in the purchase of mixers and rice cookers, which are the products her customers have asked for. Jesús is convinced that with this new merchandise, her business will grow.

Jesús is married and has three children, all in school. She is 36 years old, and she depends on her business to support her family and continue providing an education for her children.

(Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

Jesús se dedica a la venta de cosméticos y ropa en su sector y recorriendo provincias. Jesús empezó su negocio con la ayuda de una amiga que le facilito mercadería para que emprendiera su propio negocio. Al principio solo vendía cosméticos ahora ofrece este producto junto con ropa y zapatos. Jesús aspira vender artículos varios y electrodomésticos.

Ella usara el préstamo para invertir en la compra de batidoras y ollas arroceras que son productos que le están solicitando sus clientes. Jesús esta convencida que con su nueva mercadería su negocio va tener crecimiento.

Jesús esta casada tiene tres hijos todos estudian. Ella tiene 36 años, depende de su negocio para apoyar a su familia y seguirle dando la educación a sus hijos.

loans.use: She will use the loan to invest in the purchase of mixers and rice cookers.

loans.name: Joel Ramon

texts.en:
Hi, my name is Joel Ramón. I am a merchant and I own a grocery store in the center of my neighborhood. This business generates the income necessary to pay for the expenses of my family. It's important to note that thanks to the income I receive from my business, I was able to improve my home.

At the moment I need to expand my inventory to offer a better variety of products.

Translated from Spanish by Ramón F. Kolb, Kiva Volunteer.

Hola mi nombre es Joel Ramon, mi actividad principal es el comercio, cuento con una pulperia, ubicada en el centro de mi colonia, actualmente este negocio es el que me genera ingresos para cubrir los gastos de mi familia, es importante mensionar que gracias a los ingresos que persibo de este negocio he mejorado mi casa, actualmente necisto ampliar mis inventarios para poder ofrecer mayor variedad de productos.

loans.use: To buy sugar, rice, margarine, flour, soap, refreshments, diary, and chicken

loans.name: Ilgar

texts.en: Ilgar A. is a taxi driver in the town of Devechi, located on the northeastern coast of Azerbaijan. Ilgar is married with two children and is looking for funding so that he can invest in his taxi business.

loans.use: To invest in his taxi business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To Boost his Stock

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is the secretary for the Nyikira Okole Women’s Lending Group in Kikajjo on the outskirts of Kampala. She also owns SK and Sons Stationers, a secretarial bureau. She is very organized and business oriented. She has owned the business for 4 years and has a regular clientele. Sarah knows what equipment she needs to serve her customers. Currently she is able to print documents, laminate, photocopy and bind. She has 3 computers, and she also sells assorted paper.

With her loan she plans to buy another printer that will be able to scan, photocopy and print. In time, her plan is to get more machines. Eventually she will get a high-speed printer. Her business is growing and the demand is high for this professional woman’s services.

loans.use: To buy another printer for her secretarial business

loans.name: Celso

texts.es:
Mr. Celso R. lives with his wife in his own home in the San Pedro neighborhood in the city of La Paz. Mr. R. works as an urban taxi driver. The vehicle which he uses for work is deteriorating due to its age and the constant repairs that it needs are impeding his ability to work normally. The loan would be used to buy a used vehicle that is worth $2,500, of which IMPRO is financing $1,475 with their own funds, so he is requesting a loan for the remainder of the amount through KIVA. This is the tenth time that he requests a loan and the socioeconomic analysis qualifies him to receive a loan. It is worth mentioning that the previous loans were paid back within their established terms without any problems.

Translated from Spanish by Mindy Burns, Kiva volunteer.

El señor Celso R. vive en casa propia en la zona de San Pedro de la Ciudad de La Paz con su esposa, el señor Celso trabaja como chofer de taxi urbano. El vehiculo con el que trabaja esta deteriorado por su antigüedad y las constantes reparaciones que necesita impiden que pueda realizar su trabajo con normalidad. El crédito solicitado será destinado como parte de la compra de un vehiculo a medio uso. El valor total del vehiculo es de $2,500 de los cuales IMPRO está financiando $1,475 con fondos propios y la diferencia está siendo solicitada a través de KIVA. Esta es la décima ocasión que solicita un préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado los califica favorablemente y puede acceder a un crédito. Cabe mencionar que los préstamos anteriores fueron cancelados en sus plazos establecidos sin problema alguno.

loans.use: Buying a vehicle for taxi use

loans.name: Magdalene

texts.en: Magdalene O. is 50 and married with three children. She owns a poultry farm, where she raises and sells birds. She has been in LAPO for four years. She needs the loan of $700 to buy more poultry birds for sale. She studied the trade for six months and started her business in 1982.

loans.use: To buy more poultry birds for sale

loans.name: Koy

texts.en: Mrs. Koy O., 38, is a mother of eight children and lives with her husband in Boeung Sna village, Prey Veng province, Cambodia. She and her husband work on a plot of land breeding pigs and then resell them to a nearby butchers, making collectively about $10 each day in revenue. This couple has eight children. Three of them are employed by a garment factory; two others are unemployed; and the balance of their children are married and live outside the family home. Mrs. Koy O. hopes to use this loan to increase the number of pigs to meet her client demands.

loans.use: To increase the number of pigs to meet her client demand.

loans.name: Budumuli East A D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Hellen B.. She is currently in the business of grocery store and is requesting a loan to build another stall. Hellen is 29 years old and is divorced. She has 4 children ranging from age 7 to 13 and her children go to school. Each week, Hellen makes approximately UGX 60000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children Hellen has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 150000 in order to add in grocery business and the loan was paid back on time.

Hellen is joined in her small group by Mariam N., Mariam M. and Margret T. . Mariam N. has a business in selling tap water and wants to purchase more tanks and make more water connections. Mariam M. is currently operating a business in selling groceries and wants a loan to add in stock. Margret T. operates a business of retail shop and wants to add in stock and buy a weighing scale.

loans.use: To add working capital in grocery business

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Mrs. Christiana M. sells cooked food and drinks in Afro Media, Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 42 years old, married, and has 3 kids. Christiana acquired the skill of trading in 3 years and has been in business since 1993. She is requesting a loan of $1200 to enable her buy more drinks and food to sell.

loans.use: To buy more food and drink to sell.

loans.name: Erika Mercedes

texts.es:
Erika is a mother of two children, one is 10 and the other one is 6 years old. She began her business after she got a divorce from her husband. She needed a way to make a living and she decided to work for herself, that way she would not have to depend on anyone. Everything turned out as planned because she was able to pay her daily expenses and provide for her children. She began her business about eight years ago and little by little she has been able to succeed. She started out just selling just food items and other household items. Then, she decided that since she had enough space, she would open up an internet cafe in her store. Erika was able to invest her money in the internet café and then earn more money since she always has paying customers using the computers.

She needs a loan of $975 dollars. She will pay it back in 6 months. That way it will help her upgrade her computers with better programs and to stock her little store with more items. All this will make her store compete better against all the other local businesses around the block. With your help Erika’s business will grow.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela of San Roque High School, Kiva volunteer

Erika es madre de dos hijos de 10 y 6 años, inició el negocio cuando se divorcio y no tenia como salir adelante por esa razón se puso a trabajar por su cuenta para no depender de nadie y le dio resultado porque pudo cubrir sus necesidades y sacar adelante a sus hijos. Comenzó hace 8 años con el negocio y poco a poco lo ha ido mejorando, en un inicio solo vendía abarrotes y ya después lo habilite también como cibercafé para poder prestar mas servicios y aprovechar el espacio que tenia en el local. De esa manera pudo invertir el capital que tenia y sacar mas dinero ya que casi siempre tiene gente y sus ganancias se han ido incrementando con las cosas nuevas que le va incorporando al negocio.

Ella necesita un crédito por US $975 que pagara en 6 meses. El cual le va servir para poder actualizar mis pcs con mejores programas y poder surtir un poco de abarrotes el lugar. Todo esto para poder estar a la vanguardia y poder competir con los demás locales que están cerca del suyo. Con tu ayuda esto será posible.

loans.use: Update her computers

loans.name: German

texts.es:
German has a taxi operating with the Emperador radio taxi company. His home is located in Villa San Antonio Bajo, a neighbourhood of La Paz, Bolivia.

This is the second time he requests a microcredit from Impro and he plans to use the money to maintain his taxi´s motor and get a change of tires.

His work and experience as a taxi driver give him the opportunity to request this microloan since he has proven himself a responsible individual with his repayments.

Translated from Spanish by Henry Corral, Kiva volunteer.

loans.use: Maintenance of his taxi´s motor and change of tires.

loans.name: Lang

texts.en:
Lang T., 30, lives in Kampong Cham with her husband, Mann Mie, and their two children. She works in a little grocery store business that she owns and typically makes US$2 each day. Her husband is a farmer and spends his days out in the fields, making less than US$1 each day. They have been at these jobs for many years and have been struggling to support themselves and their two young children. Rising inflation has had a devastating impact on many Cambodian families over the course of this past year and Lang T. has been seeking out ways to increase her daily income. She has asked for a loan of US$200 to increase her grocery inventory. She believes that an investment in her grocery business can increase her profits and expand her store. She wants an opportunity to increase her family’s income and improve their standard of living.



Lang T. was unavailable for a photo at the time of the interview, so her husband, Mann Mie, is pictured above.

loans.use: Increase grocery inventory

loans.name: Loa

texts.en:
Loa S., 24, is the mother of one little child and lives with her husband in Kampong Chhnang province, Cambodia. She is a tailor, working out of her home and earns approximately US$ 2 in profit each day. Her husband, Phal Chamroeun, 28, is a staff member in a micro-finance institution in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.

Loa would like to borrow from Kiva via "Credit", Kiva's local partner, US$ 200 to purchase feed for their pigs.

loans.use: To purchase feed for pigs

loans.name: Ariana Lizeth

texts.es:
Ariana tiene un pequeño de 6 meses, Raúl Antonio quien es el motor de su vida. Ella inicio el negocio para salir adelante con una actividad que le diera buenos ingresos, y actualmente lo hace para sacar adelante a su hijo ya que ella es la que se hace cargo de la manutención de su pequeño. Comenzó hace 7 años vendiendo comidas en su casa posterior mente rento un local y se amplio.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $400 que pagara en 6 meses para invertirlo en su negocio.
texts.en:
Ariana has a six-month-old, Raúl Antonio, who drives everything in her life. She started the business to get ahead through a venture that would provide her with good income.
