Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase two calves

loans.name: Tabita

texts.en: Tabita T. is currently in the business of selling onions, bananas, and tomatoes. She is requesting a loan to stock more tomatoes and onions to sell.  Tabita is 23 years old and is married to a farmer. She has no children yet. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: To stock more tomatoes and onions to sell.

loans.name: Kimenyedde Women's Group-Kayunga

texts.en: For the last 13 years, 39-year-old N. John has  been running a farm supplies business in Mayangayanga-Kayunga.  He says to begin this business he got ideas and knowledge from an apprentice colleague and mobilized start-up capital.  John also operates a veterinary shop. John is married with six kids and in a week, his profits amount to shillings 100,000. With this loan he says he is going to purchase more manure, hoes, pangas (machetes), etc. to supply to farmers in his locality. John belongs to Kimenyedde Women’s group-Kayunga.

loans.use: The purchase of more manure, hoes and pangas (machetes)

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina N. is married and lives with her husband, 2 student children, and her in-laws. A teacher in the past, since 2002 Marina has been trading women’s clothing and underwear from a rented shop in one of the city’s markets. 

In the past, Marina used to travel to the neighbouring countries to purchase inventory. Now, Marina puts her orders through other traders so she can spend more time managing the shop.  Currently Marina requires new stock for the shop. With a good credit history behind her, to help her finance the inventory order, Marina has applied to SEF International for a loan.

loans.use: To purchase clothes inventory

loans.name: Carlina's Group

texts.en:
Carlina G. is from the village of Manaoag, Cauayan City, Isabela.  Carlina, who is 60 years old, is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Carlina is married and has 6 adult-aged children. To make a living, Carlina sells animal feed to local farmers. Carlina has been engaged in her business for more than 15 years and earns approximately 6500 PHP a month.

In 2008, Carlina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carlina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Carlina is requesting a new loan, her fifth from ASKI, for 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Athanase

texts.en:
Greetings from Rwanda!  Athanase is 40 years old and is married, with two children who are 4 and 8 years old.  He owns a small general store and employs one person.

Athanase has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to help expand his business by purchasing a large quantity of sugar and rice, as they are in high demand. He has lots of plans for any profits that he makes from the business.  These include renovating his house, paying school fees for his two children, as well as building a secure future for his children.

loans.use: To purchase a large quantity  of sugar and rice.

loans.name: Mubariz

texts.en: Mubariz A. is a 59 year-old man, married, with four children. He is an internal refugee from Nagorno-Karabakh who fled to the Sabirabad district of Azerbaijan in 1993. Mubariz is the head of his large family and the hardship of being refugees made it difficult for him support them. That is why in 2004 he started his animal breeding and selling business with the little savings he had. He gradually expanded his business, which is the only source of income for his family. His sons, who are 24 and 28, actively help him in business. Now he has seven cows and a monthly income of 300 AZN. This is his second loan from AqroInvest and Kiva. After successfully repaying his previous loan he requested another loan of 1300 AZN to buy three cows. In the future Mubariz wants to expand his business and have a farm.

loans.use: to buy three cows

loans.name: Virgie

texts.en:
Virgie D. C. is from the village of Eastern Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 37 years old. Virgie is married and has three school-aged children. 

To make a living, Virgie runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling eggs, bananas and vegetables like squash in the local community. Virgie has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

Virgie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Virgie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. 

Virgie is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products, like bananas, to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Virgie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell
